Author: koolmoe
Content:
I think the lack of a physical keyboard will have minimal impact on the success or failure of the iPhone.

Consider that millions of users adapted to the clunky text message interfaces of their cell phones. They aren't going to balk at a virtual keyboard, especially when the tradeoff is that you get a much larger screen for viewing video. A consumer that wouldn't buy the phone for lack of a physical keyboard probably isn't in the target market anyway.\n

Author: sajid
Content:
You're not required to host your application with facebook

Infact, Facebook does not host any outside applications.

'Hosting' your application on the Facebook platform can be as simple sticking it in an iframe.\n

Author: cwilbur
Content: If I wanted to be called by strangers from YC, I'd put my phone number in my profile.

Author: aaroneous
Content: If you're based in California and do most of your business in CA, it might make sense incorporate in California instead of Delaware. CA has in the last few years made its laws more business friendly, and if you incorporate in CA you'll avoid having to pay certain taxes and fees twice (once for each state). There are a few other benefits DE has, but probably none of them will be useful at your early-mid stage company. Definitely worth looking in to.

Author: brianmckenzie
Content:
Peanut, you've hit on something of importance, that I was mis-valuing before: do I need his money?

Upon further reflection, I probably don't need it. And when I reach the stage where I do need it, I probably want to get it from a real angel investor. Even if that didn't work out, I still have better places to get funding than this guy.

Guess I'll just have to pay a lawyer who specializes in tech startups.

This really clarifies the decision. Thanks!

Author: paulgb
Content: Agreed. Many of the bad things she mentioned are things I consider positive things (privacy settings, non-customizable look). The article almost goes back and forth between describing things myspace has that facebook doesn't, and things that are easy to ask for but hard to do. Neither of these categories justifies hate, even if it is just an attention grabber.

Author: keiretsu
Content:
i think most of the business fogeys don't understand the importance of having your own in house technical team. these fogeys actually think outsourcing development to offshore teams is the best way to go.

Right. Technology is the lifeblood of most successful web startups. So when was it good to outsource your lifeblood to a bunch of unknowns miles away?
